than in the adult males and they are supported by the 
frontal bone as in the female Gnu Plate III. The structure also of the horncores affords a character of very great 
importance in the determination of the affinities of the 
animal. The section made of the horncore in the Coll. of 
Surgeons (3817) proves that it consists of a compact spongy 
mass solid for at least eighth of its length and with a 
simple vacuity merely at its base, That this character 
is constant is proved by the section of the fossil horncore 
from Crayford as well as by the observations of M. Lartet (1) 
In <s>the<\s> Bos, Bison and Bubalus the frontal sinuses are 
prolonged as far as the end of the horncores (2), while in Ovis and Capra 
they are never prolonged further than the middle and very 
frequently they do not enter the horncores at all, as in 
some of the antelopes. In the compactness then of its horncores 
<u>Ovibos Moschatus<u> is <s>separated from Bos, Bubalus and Bison 
and<\s> allied to Ovis <s>and Capra<\s>, while in their position on the 
parietal in the old male, it stands apart from all these 
subgenera. Among the points of difference between Ovibos 
and <u>Bubalus Caffir<\u> is the enormous develop<s>e<\s>ment of 
the frontal sinuses in the latter which cause the 
coronal surface to assume the form of a segment of a 
circle antero-posteriorly while in the former the corresponding 
surface is but slightly curved. 
The facial aspect. <s>The fronto-nasal suture, extends nearly at 
right angles to the median line instead of being directed 
obliquely forwards at a very acute angle as in the Ovis 
Capra, Bos and especially Bubalus Caffir.<\s> Running transversely 
across the parietals at a short distance from the orbit is
